8B4893F3690D406DB82533C775F55AC1.description: Identify what resources, goods, and services are available in the neighborhoods being studied, and explain how people obtain those resources and how the environment influences resource availability

BE8F655161CA4AF5B08DCC7795612C5E.description: Explain what the physical environment is like for the neighborhoods being studied, and analyze how that influences the way a neighborhood is organized

899CD3C2722A4966B96A047075C60FA1.description: Analyze differences among urban, suburban, and rural neighborhoods around the globe and the relationship to population

B0CE9DE1603A4B4A977A025471263BE6.description: Analyze similarities and differences between the characteristics of neighborhoods around the globe and the students' neighborhoods (e.g., the way the neighborhood is organized spatially, who neighborhood leaders are, what traditions are celebrated, what buildings and places are there)

FF9151110BFA467FAB58B8F9B187E7E6.description: Identify the physical locations of the neighborhoods being looked at and their locations on a map or globe

B3FBA18D0E0F40CBA951837F2DD3BDEC.description: Analyze the similarities and differences in what neighborhoods are like in places around the world.

0EF6DE349ADC4CB9A35534D23404732F.description: Explain what the physical environment is like at the school location, and analyze how that influences the ways a school is organized and run

2BEC519AE1EF4E0F9584DD927A13745A.description: Analyze similarities and differences between the characteristics of schools around the globe and the students' school (e.g., school buildings, schedules, who gets to go, grades/ages)

785909934DF34DC28444CDF24DBD03C6.description: Identify the physical locations of the schools being studied and their locations on a map or globe

294B3E4D68B3466DA496ED2D7D497A57.description: Analyze the similarities and differences in what school is like around the world.

1F0BC8C69BD04B83888690480831D7E1.description: Identify what resources are available to the families being studied, and explain how they obtain those resources and how environment influences resource availability

F1B7A59EDDE94856A77B7405ECC9FB8D.description: Explain what the physical environment is like for the families being studied, and analyze how that influences their ways of life

D6C27458BB294BE2BFB175067C0D686B.description: Analyze similarities and differences between the characteristics of families around the globe and the students' families (e.g., homes, food, clothing, traditions)

397946690FBF4A598260C8ADB15252E3.description: Identify on a map or globe where the families being studied live throughout the world

D70A454A6D2D43B88021606D0E88D37B.description: Analyze families and family traditions in other parts of the world.

50418830988F4C4DBFDC1A232A880692.description: Analyze similarities between celebrations and traditions learned in this unit to those learned during the unit on family and school and those learned through literature

F66112C483904B7EA5EA1A2A30330439.description: Explain differences and similarities between cultural celebrations and traditions (e.g., Dominican Festival and Parade, Veterans Day commemorations, Founders' Day celebrations, Fourth of July parades)

089932723D3F4AB2B6645D11A542BDE4.description: Identify local traditions and celebrations, and explain how different communities observe them

57D73B657BC6472CB8E844BBE2F372E5.description: Analyze similarities and differences between diverse traditions and celebrations from local neighborhoods, communities, and those represented in literature.

F240FC3B67B64237912182E3619BECB9.description: Identify where in the community students can go for help (e.g., trusted adult, emergency services), and explain how to get help (e.g., call 911, talk to school counselor)

3E67A5985F3945A19FBFA0FE547170BD.description: Explain ways to help people in the local neighborhood or community

229738ADFF634BD6965185F35A44CDEE.description: Identify different community helpers (e.g., mayor, police, firefighters, teachers, doctors, cashiers), and analyze the ways they help people

46AE1A503E534527B60F11A6C1BAFBE7.description: Explain community rules and norms, who makes them, and ways rules and norms contribute to the health of the community

A7FD897EEB69471DA4CA5B3E3C62387E.description: Explain why people have responsibilities to each other, and analyze actions people take to show civility to each other

5B8A1461C39D4D8FA32008DBC8685DDC.description: Analyze the ways members of a community interact, help each other, and contribute to the community as a whole.

2562AC0B091047389BA78F793F727A6F.description: Analyze the similarities and differences between students' neighborhoods and those of their classmates (e.g., landscape, population, availability of resources)

EC1D0FEBC5F842729B3EB72BDE3E67DD.description: Explain what resources are available in students' neighborhoods and larger communities (e.g., schools, trees, stores, rivers, health services, recreation), and analyze how those resources are made available, and to whom

60138B1425584DA6BDA000A8839993A1.description: Identify the geographical landscape of students' neighborhoods (e.g., urban, rural, suburban, has trees, hilly)

0010C4724D7044198913E6612415BEBF.description: Identify boundaries of a neighborhood versus the larger community

12483414B4C746C59040B6E2A2F58F6A.description: Identify buildings and places in students' neighborhoods (e.g., school, library, places of worship, community centers), and explain their locations in relation to each other

76E0F1DE15664F3981EF38622B0FFB5C.description: Analyze the relationship between geography, location, and resource availability in how neighborhoods and communities are defined.

B5C0BE63A20E49A7949E2AE731B10020.description: Identify the differences and similarities between how holidays and traditions are celebrated at school and at home

EBDAB64AFBCA4CD8A1C43CFEE37784BC.description: Identify people, holidays, and traditions that are celebrated and the historical events they represent (e.g., Labor Day, Indigenous Peoples' Day / Columbus Day, Veterans Day, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Presidents' Day, Juneteenth, Memorial Day)

194B7F996F074C88A2C072C73BEDEF66.description: Identify school traditions (e.g., special school-specific traditions like field day, spirit week)

D7BC3456E6D8447B9075670EB1C1BEA9.description: Explain traditions and holidays that are celebrated and recognized at school.

28ECBAA897D04A03981FAFBA59BFF786.description: Explain the words in the Pledge of Allegiance and why it is recited at school

1819321F80EC4DA69417A06C1893DE58.description: Identify the United States flag at school as a way to show national pride

FD3B8640E2784B7CA57910C9879ED2C0.description: Identify school symbols (e.g., mascot, school colors) and ways to show school pride

4001BAF41AAA4931B02A975BAE038672.description: Explain ways to help in the classroom and at school

38E23729AF3246FB9ABC838FE7396863.description: Explain responsibilities that students have to each other

00BC337AC5E5417ABE086C1AF12E470D.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of being classroom citizens.

00246D95C1AE477DA55E8F3581EFE15A.description: Analyze the responsibilities of people at school and at home and how they work together to help students to learn effectively (e.g., teachers, principal, class helpers, custodian, family caregivers)

7A1938A01AD64042AC3972B3DFE5D387.description: Argue how the rules, norms, and rights at school help students to learn and teachers to teach and how they create a way for students to work together

38AE3FD49EB84243B313EC9395A2F691.description: Analyze differences in rules in different places like at home, at school, or in public

63F70C2FC7A4426C8D837CE6A3903A3E.description: Identify rules and norms of school within the classroom and in other spaces at school (e.g., cafeteria, hallways)

A3E07AB38A8947F48629827AD0350AA3.description: Analyze rules, roles, and responsibilities at school.

F60170547F4240BC9920634C0A9FD3D2.description: Analyze what the school provides for the local community socially and how the local community helps the school

C37DF015071A4C9193A604DEE030B972.description: Explain the relative location of the school in relation to other nearby resources such as stores, services, etc.

B95D3633BFB3480AA591529D1BFDCE53.description: Explain the relative location of the school in relation to where the students live

D2999DC69B69438386E01419E5A63D4C.description: Identify the school's address and its location on a map

FDCEBE32409343C082896A9A3F60B142.description: Analyze the school's place within the local community geographically, socially, and economically.

2370B122D0CB4D4BB2ABC0FBB561EE25.description: Explain ways jobs provide resources to the community

71BE42266A4A4D1693BCFA9DD402DBA2.description: Explain what income is and the role of money in obtaining goods and services

DEEB9B3637784D00850142ADAA01B794.description: Identify ways jobs are determined by where one lives (e.g., closeness to the family) or ways jobs may determine where one lives (e.g., moving to be closer to a job)

1B65ECD0576042399C7898FBF23851A3.description: Explain what jobs are, different types of jobs, and how they are used to obtain wants and needs

95E807410BFF447FB5995BEEDB7235E5.description: Explain scarcity and ways wants and needs play out with limited resources

3E6EC60017974C05958604F00B665339.description: Explain ways families share and distribute resources

357F31705EB34EB7A4B26CD6383B97C0.description: Identify family wants and needs, and explain how wants and needs are important in understanding the responsibilities individuals have to each other and the family as a whole

DD99092D8A264588AF633BBB4DAC898B.description: Explain the differences between needs and wants and how these concepts impact family units.

80F129DC7F734880AF0B17E61A040703.description: Identify differences and similarities between the traditions of their families, their classmates' families, and those represented in literature

33FC71ABA45C40F6A6AC60F789771B24.description: Identify ways students can explore the different traditions of people in their community

27B945BAB57F465BB1AE95EC3CDC3301.description: Explain ways in which where people live can affect traditions

6E0881EDFA964FCE8016B1DBACD070C1.description: Identify family traditions as they relate to culture (e.g., food, clothing, activities, holidays, religion)

6D74D4F05D2C4CE4858B6598DAC1BCC2.description: Identify the characteristics of culture (e.g., food, clothing, activities, holidays, religion)

3043E7FB45644FD792096B130AD9EC8A.description: Explain a variety of family and cultural traditions through looking at the students' own, those of classmates, and those represented in literature.

68C8BA1AF41E4ACFB694E47E74E66538.description: Explain how families make up neighborhoods and neighborhoods create, are a part of, and influence the larger community

F17A9C368EAB4C6E80633C43FE7A453E.description: Explain the physical environment where students live

6B37C629D605474786A011008E389FE2.description: Identify the location of the student's home address and addresses to important places and relative locations near their home

056F76BEEFA24F88A806C1D9F14E1714.description: Identify resources near families and resources that are farther away (e.g., schools, stores, services for the unhoused, disability services)

D4B81C90416046E0B1C5D21CE9138A35.description: Identify the purpose and features of a map and a globe and the locations of where students and their classmates live (e.g., city/town, state, and country)

BAC24FDAEDAD4FB491A762FD0C50D87D.description: Explain the physical location of students' and classmates' families within the community and the relationships between families and the community.

D145D37CDEDB4D029F074B3A0D600BD7.description: Explain ways to help at home

3698D486D9FB49A389D85D4D2B7E7C5F.description: Explain responsibilities that members of a family have to the family unit (including to pets)

69213A881E114E6E8FBA19DFFBAABC6B.description: Identify what rules and norms families have, and explain who makes them and why they exist

25D56F3D5C824B37AB4A9CC7C87BCB83.description: Identify roles people have in a family unit, and explain how the roles relate to each other

FAB3407AF8014D05B86BBEE2F3BD5C93.description: Identify examples and configurations of a family unit, and explain the characteristics of what makes a family (e.g., adopted families, foster families, heterosexual couple families, families with same sex caregivers, interracial families, families with a single caregiver, extended families)

469C9C794B4B47AC9B948F9ED4F23B06.description: Explain families, family roles, and family rules through looking at the student's own, those of classmates, and those represented in literature.

42707A86F2404F22B3E1B9CFD4F016B9.description: Kindergarten - Living and Working Together in Schools, Families, and Neighborhoods

D02E0500F5804ECDAFADB85172F24280.description: Argue how different economic systems can create more equitable outcomes for individuals and communities, particularly for those traditionally marginalized from the economic system.

230891283D7A48CA85086A3A21CEE42B.description: Analyze how inequities within the economic system have been addressed or sustained by the actions of those traditionally privileged and marginalized.

6398F3E9DACC4139990FA829C9E9DDD4.description: Explain how those traditionally privileged and marginalized across intersecting identities can influence and interact with economic systems.

1223240AD51E43FC9CEDAD75A3F9D24A.description: Identify the ways that different political systems utilize economic systems to organize and distribute goods and services to individuals and communities.

7BB46D64DDD54B9884B94F75E3B5A711.description: Argue whether the costs and benefits of an aspect of the means of production equitably serve all individuals and communities.

F6C2B1E43E1B4E3ABCC7D171D7B8D5AD.description: Analyze how individuals and communities acting through intersectional identities and lived experiences can affect the means of production.

A3A0CE6926E24CF49C044103AC81C023.description: Explain who has the power to make decisions related to the means of production and the effects those decisions have on individuals and communities

5887C7EC344F4A26BEA68150F5C22757.description: Identify the individuals and communities involved in the production of any good or service, the materials needed for producing them, where and how the materials are obtained, and the various interrelationships among all of these elements.

1836229329A440339110576DACE3DC3D.description: Argue how a resource can be used differently to create a more equitable outcome for individuals and communities including how individuals and communities can influence systems of power to achieve that change.

8FA26EAF436F4C80A3F6892F7E0E340E.description: Analyze how decisions affecting access to goods and services are influenced by systems of power and cultural norms including how these effects of decisions create more equitable or inequitable outcomes.

DD5F616360EE478B9B789DCD0C9B18BB.description: Explain how scarcity affects the cost and availability of desired goods and services, and who has the power to influence the factors related to cost and availability and why.

A9C0AA3886F74D1BB57C9301E264868C.description: Identify the choices communities make about how to use resources based on the scarcity of that resource, including those that are familiar and unfamiliar.

0DC60C579906488C9990049425420F09.description: Argue how the systematic analysis of the spatial patterns provides an integral understanding of a place or region and supports equitable decisions about climate and land use.

364AB0DA681C42FDA7B1DA5D4B0547E2.description: Analyze multiple types of maps, charts, and graphs and how they are used to interpret topographical information, draw inferences about the development of societies, and determine how places shape events and how places may be changed by events.

F2F18CCAFED6403C9054EFBFF98A0973.description: Explain how the characteristics and elements of maps, globes, geographic tools, and other technologies are used and selected to identify and describe local, regional and/or global locations.

5318E42EAFFB480CAA74279F6CB0633D.description: Identify maps, globes, and other geographic tools and technologies that are used to describe where places are located both absolutely and relatively across time, space, and distance.

DBF814CBB6BD41C8AE11883AC1F484B6.description: Argue how decisions about resources and the environment made by individuals and/or communities impact current and future peoples differently and how those decisions might be made more equitable.

913558C3A5BB4D04BE57ED3823369A41.description: Analyze how individuals and societies at local, regional and/or global levels influence political, economic, and social decision-making.

C6F9C66E68CA4B0D8709D9FA7F5147F5.description: Explain how humans and their societies and institutions affect, modify and/or preserve the environment, as well as how the modifications of the physical environment affect physical, behavioral, and diverse cultural systems.

A7E93AC328744568B3A62140A5CA6E09.description: Identify the characteristics of human systems, physical systems, and the environment, and ways they interact at local, regional and/or global levels.

74F41077C564488C8F79E4EA98764D21.description: Argue how the relationship between populations and physical systems influence decision-making about the equitable access to resources and land at the local, regional, and/or global levels.

A04005AD73604613B341F3EB0FBDC73A.description: Analyze how human systems and the distribution of populations interact with and impact physical systems, and how conflict and access to resources influence physical systems.

B469731A77FB4149BB1435D9880992CD.description: Explain how and why a population's characteristics, including their spatial distribution, growth, and movement, have divided, organized, and unified areas of Earth's surface and impacted both human and physical systems.

DA2ABD428B7B4E499789F01A36FA6CBA.description: Identify the characteristics of populations based on their size, place, region, and cultural demographics, as well as identifying patterns of migration.

6B9829C7D9EF414AA0B00E175F9F68A8.description: Argue how all individuals can act as local, national, and/or global agents of social change by using lessons learned from history.

4A032F3CF45345B9B49B8BCF178AB1FA.description: Analyze historical change through the intersectional identities and lived experiences of people who have accomplished social change throughout history in relation to systems of power, identity, and resistance.

0C8C86A45C444D9CB446050DD80F80EB.description: Explain how historical and social change have been and continue to be accomplished in relation to systems of power, identity, and resistance.

1647CF85EB9D417894F886723283C36F.description: Identify peoples, events, technologies, and ideas involved in historical and social change in various geographical and temporal locations.

4497BF0DA2D1411B89810F45D293CA21.description: Argue, using multiple narratives rooted in identity, power, and resistance, how history itself is an interpretation of events.

1302F67469F2488A98763707EF95BD31.description: Analyze multiple types of sources, including art, music, oral histories, pamphlets, film, texts, etc., through a critical reflection of the creators' and students' intersectional identities and lived experiences.

5067CDCBC325469CABFE9F266F7A9CCB.description: Explain the purpose, audience, and perspective of multiple types of sources (art, music, oral histories, pamphlets, film, texts, etc.) relating to a historical event or series of events, individual, or group of people, including indications of bias toward or against the subject portrayed.

E6D76B8B77934A47BE90EBB8B4228300.description: Identify key people, central ideas, and the mechanisms by which stories are told and retold regarding an event or series of events, centering the voices of historical actors and groups engaged in resistance and change.

382A562651D841C19F6101398EE59C47.description: Argue how social change, intersectional identities, and lived experiences are crucial to the study and practice of history.

669B4829E0954378B8B64742ADE9870C.description: Analyze multiple sources to compare and contrast historical events through the lenses of identity, power, and resistance.

1FA4883C38F246B3A414CBDC2761718F.description: Explain multiple causes and effects of historical events, centering and representing the voices and experiences of individuals and communities who were agents of change and resistance.

36FA661DDE1E48A2A6B16FD262E2BCAF.description: Identify historical events that are culturally relevant to global, national, and local histories and connect to students' intersectional identities and lived experiences.

2AF5277485494DB2A97E4632F624DEA4.description: Argue for a possible solution to make rights equitable and the roles of those involved in pursuing that solution.

CB883A35EDEC49CC8AADC6EB564EF10F.description: Analyze how individuals and communities have been included or excluded from the political process based on their intersectional identities and lived experiences and the impact these actions have had on their rights, responsibilities, and the functioning of a democratic society.

00819FB537E747F79942DB949E83C1FB.description: Explain different ways communities and individuals inform themselves, exercise their rights and responsibilities, and engage formally and/or informally in political processes.

A14E94A045A84726A6832DA3AADBA979.description: Identify what rights and responsibilities individuals and communities have in a society and who can take advantage of them.

61B80C938C204BD39949AEB816E87371.description: Argue how rules and laws can be used to create an equitable society.

0BBBA0E29329433EB9B643838939E035.description: Analyze how rules and laws positively and/or negatively impact different individuals and communities based on their intersectional identities and lived experiences.

EDDE8BF65E78461BBD0B31D2AAD53745.description: Explain why rules and laws exist, and how they are implemented by and for individuals and communities based on their intersectional identities and lived experiences.

382087E84D5C4A48B7A9F1FCB30FF837.description: Identify what rules and laws are, and who has the power to make them, in different settings and cultures that are familiar and unfamiliar to students.

0AA6706B1E20493DA151A5D7A4DF304B.description: Argue how power can be distributed and used to create a more equitable society for communities and individuals based on their intersectional identities and lived experiences.

FBEB1DA823AF467489CDCFD17E65AAA7.description: Analyze the purpose of government and the use of power, including balancing order and freedom, to advance and control different communities and individuals based on their intersectional identities and lived experiences.

326C42F56F044B878C9A77F80341B679.description: Explain how political power is and has been obtained and used to govern communities and individuals with attention to their intersectional identities and lived experiences.

E34FF08930EC4A1CB39C79321FDDBD48.description: Identify what political power is and who has political power in a society.
